title: How to Easily Clean a Garlic Press

steps.headline: Trim off the plastic or paper off one end of the garbage tie, giving about an inch of wire.
Poke through the holes of the garlic press, using this new tool, clearing the holes of any sticking garlic.
Remember that usually the garlic drops out from the press after this has happened, but if not, run the press under warm water.
Give the garlic press a little rinse, and you're done.
Use a knife to scrape off and out obvious garlic that is stuck on either side of the mincer.
steps.description: Do this over the sink, using running water if wished.

steps.headline: Cut a small piece of potato.
steps.description: It must be small enough to fit inside the mincer, the same size as a garlic clove. If you're using potatoes in your cooking for the same meal, set aside a little piece from those potatoes.

steps.headline: Push the potato through the mincer.
steps.description: It will come out easily through the other side and will bring with it the rest of the stuck garlic. Best of all it removes the odor of crushed garlic. A small piece of bread can be substituted for the potato and will work just as effectively. It's a good use of discarded crusts!

steps.headline: Wash in the dish washing water as usual.
steps.description: Allow to air dry; this is more effective than trying to towel dry it.

text: Garbage tie method Find an ordinary garbage tie.  Trim off the plastic or paper off one end of the garbage tie, giving about an inch of wire.  Poke through the holes of the garlic press, using this new tool, clearing the holes of any sticking garlic.  Remember that usually the garlic drops out from the press after this has happened, but if not, run the press under warm water.  Give the garlic press a little rinse, and you're done. Congratulations! Potato method Use a knife to scrape off and out obvious garlic that is stuck on either side of the mincer. Do this over the sink, using running water if wished. Cut a small piece of potato. It must be small enough to fit inside the mincer, the same size as a garlic clove. If you're using potatoes in your cooking for the same meal, set aside a little piece from those potatoes. Push the potato through the mincer. It will come out easily through the other side and will bring with it the rest of the stuck garlic. Best of all it removes the odor of crushed garlic. A small piece of bread can be substituted for the potato and will work just as effectively. It's a good use of discarded crusts! Wash in the dish washing water as usual. Allow to air dry; this is more effective than trying to towel dry it.
sentences: Garbage tie method Find an ordinary garbage tie.
Trim off the plastic or paper off one end of the garbage tie, giving about an inch of wire.
Poke through the holes of the garlic press, using this new tool, clearing the holes of any sticking garlic.
Remember that usually the garlic drops out from the press after this has happened, but if not, run the press under warm water.
Give the garlic press a little rinse, and you're done.
Potato method Use a knife to scrape off and out obvious garlic that is stuck on either side of the mincer.
Do this over the sink, using running water if wished.
Cut a small piece of potato.
It must be small enough to fit inside the mincer, the same size as a garlic clove.
If you're using potatoes in your cooking for the same meal, set aside a little piece from those potatoes.
Push the potato through the mincer.
It will come out easily through the other side and will bring with it the rest of the stuck garlic.
Best of all it removes the odor of crushed garlic.
A small piece of bread can be substituted for the potato and will work just as effectively.
It's a good use of discarded crusts!
Wash in the dish washing water as usual.
Allow to air dry; this is more effective than trying to towel dry it.
tyn_section: Potato (and knife to cut); or bread
